description: From Middle French perpendiculaire, from Old French perpendiculer, from Latin perpendiculum (“plumb line”).

adjectives.description: perpendicular (comparative more perpendicular, superlative most perpendicular)

entries.meaning: (geometry) at or forming a right angle (to something).
examples: In most houses, the walls are perpendicular to the floor.

entries.meaning: Exactly upright; extending in a straight line toward the centre of the earth, etc.
Independent of or irrelevant to each other; orthogonal.
examples: Hey, I'm not unsabotaging anything! This is completely perpendicular sabotage!

entries.meaning: (geometry) A line or plane that is perpendicular to another.
A device such as a plumb line that is used in making or marking a perpendicular line.
(obsolete, slang) A meal eaten at a tavern bar while standing up.
